name: Kinalas
description: A Bicol dish consisting of noodles (pancit) garnished by scraped meat from pork or beef's head and other parts, enhanced with a thick deep-brown sauce coming from the brains of a cow or pig.
ingredients: 2 tablespoons cornstarch, dissolved in 1/4 cup water
instructions: In a large pot, boil the pork or beef bones and meat with water. Skim off any scum that forms on the surface.
Add the onion, garlic, star anise, fish sauce, and soy sauce. Simmer for 1-2 hours or until the meat is tender.
Remove the meat from the broth, let it cool, then shred it into pieces.
Strain the broth to remove the bones and spices. Return the broth to the pot and bring it to a boil.
Add the dissolved cornstarch to the boiling broth to thicken it. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Cook the egg noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
To serve, place some noodles in a bowl, add the shredded meat, and pour the thickened broth over them.
Garnish with boiled egg, chopped spring onions, crispy garlic bits, and a squeeze of calamansi or lemon.

name: Bicol Express
description: a spicy Filipino stew made with two signature ingredients of Bicol cuisine: fiery-hot chilies and creamy coconut milk.
ingredients: 1 kg pork belly, cut into strips
6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
2-4 pieces bird's eye chili (siling labuyo), chopped (optional, for extra spiciness)
instructions: In a large pan, sauté garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant.
Add the pork belly strips and cook until they turn slightly brown.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for about 20-30 minutes or until the pork is tender.
Add the shrimp paste and mix well. Continue to simmer until the sauce thickens and the oil starts to separate from the coconut milk.
Add the long green chili peppers and bird's eye chili (if using). Cook for another 5-10 minutes or until the chilies are tender.
Pour in the coconut cream and simmer for an additional 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Laing
description: A Filipino dish of shredded or whole taro leaves with meat or seafood cooked in thick coconut milk spiced with labuyo chili, lemongrass, garlic, shallots, ginger, and shrimp paste.
ingredients: 6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
2-4 pieces bird's eye chili (siling labuyo), chopped (optional, for extra spiciness)
instructions: In a large pot, combine coconut milk, garlic, onion, ginger, and shrimp paste. Bring to a boil.
Add the pork belly or shrimp (if using) and cook until tender.
Lower the heat and add the dried taro leaves. Press them down to soak in the coconut milk mixture. Do not stir to avoid releasing the itchy substance from the taro leaves.
Add the long green chili peppers and bird's eye chili (if using). Simmer for about 15-20 minutes or until the taro leaves are tender and the sauce has thickened.
Pour in the coconut cream and cook for another 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Pancit Bato
description: A local noodle dish made with Pancit Bato noodles, named after the town of Bato in Camarines Sur. It is typically sautéed with meat, vegetables, and soy sauce.
instructions: Boil Pancit Bato noodles until tender. Drain and set aside.
In a large pan, heat the cooking oil over medium heat. Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add the sliced pork or chicken and cook until browned.
Add the carrots and cabbage, and cook for a few minutes until vegetables are tender.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, and chicken broth. Stir well to combine.
Add the cooked Pancit Bato noodles and mix well until all ingredients are evenly distributed.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with chopped spring onions before serving.

name: Pinangat
description: A traditional Bicolano dish made with gabi (taro) leaves, filled with meat or fish, and cooked in coconut milk.
ingredients: 6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
instructions: Prepare the filling: In a pan, heat some oil and saute the onion, garlic, and ginger until fragrant.
Add the ground pork or fish and shrimp paste. Cook until the meat is browned and cooked through.
Season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside to cool slightly.
Prepare the gabi leaves: If the leaves are large, cut them into squares or rectangles. Blanch the leaves in boiling water for a few minutes to soften them. Drain and set aside.
Assemble the pinangat: Place a spoonful of the filling in the center of each gabi leaf. Fold the sides of the leaf to enclose the filling. Secure the sides with toothpicks or string (optional).

In a pot, arrange the pinangat packets in a single layer. Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the gabi leaves are tender and cooked through.
Stir in the coconut cream and simmer for an additional 2-3 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste (optional).
Serve hot with steamed rice.
